trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus queues (Node.js) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus queues (Node.js) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Service Bus queues in Azure from a Node.js app.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Service Bus queues in Azure from a Node.js app.

trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus queues
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus queues

trans-unit.source: This guide describes how to use Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: This guide describes how to use Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in JavaScript and use the Node.js Azure module.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in JavaScript and use the Node.js Azure module.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include creating queues, sending and receiving messages, and deleting queues.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include creating queues, sending and receiving messages, and deleting queues.

trans-unit.source: For more information on queues, see the [Next steps] section.
trans-unit.target: For more information on queues, see the [Next steps] section.

trans-unit.source: Create a Node.js application
trans-unit.target: Create a Node.js application

trans-unit.source: Create a blank Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: Create a blank Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on creating a Node.js application, see [Create and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Web Site], or <link><linkText>Node.js Cloud Service[node.js cloud service]</linkText><title></title></link> (using Windows PowerShell).
trans-unit.target: For instructions on creating a Node.js application, see [Create and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Web Site], or <link><linkText>Node.js Cloud Service[node.js cloud service]</linkText><title></title></link> (using Windows PowerShell).

trans-unit.source: Configure your application to use Service Bus
trans-unit.target: Configure your application to use Service Bus

trans-unit.source: To use Azure Service Bus, download and use the Node.js azure package.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure Service Bus, download and use the Node.js azure package.

trans-unit.source: This includes a set of libraries that communicate with the Service Bus REST services.
trans-unit.target: This includes a set of libraries that communicate with the Service Bus REST services.

trans-unit.source: Use Node Package Manager (NPM) to obtain the package
trans-unit.target: Use Node Package Manager (NPM) to obtain the package

trans-unit.source: Use the Windows PowerShell for Node.js command window to navigate to the c:\\node\\sbqueues\\WebRole1 folder in which you created your sample application.
trans-unit.target: Use the Windows PowerShell for Node.js command window to navigate to the c:\\node\\sbqueues\\WebRole1 folder in which you created your sample application.

trans-unit.source: Type npm install azure in the command window, which should result in output similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: Type npm install azure in the command window, which should result in output similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: You can manually run the ls command to verify that a node\_modules folder was created.
trans-unit.target: You can manually run the ls command to verify that a node\_modules folder was created.

trans-unit.source: Inside that folder find the azure package, which contains the libraries you need to access Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: Inside that folder find the azure package, which contains the libraries you need to access Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: Import the module
trans-unit.target: Import the module

trans-unit.source: Using Notepad or another text editor, add the following to the top of the server.js file of the application:
trans-unit.target: Using Notepad or another text editor, add the following to the top of the server.js file of the application:

trans-unit.source: Set up an Azure Service Bus connection
trans-unit.target: Set up an Azure Service Bus connection

trans-unit.source: The Azure module reads the environment variables AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_NAMESPACE and AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_ACCESS\_KEY to obtain information required to connect to Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: The Azure module reads the environment variables AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_NAMESPACE and AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_ACCESS\_KEY to obtain information required to connect to Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the account information when calling createServiceBusService.
trans-unit.target: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the account information when calling createServiceBusService.

trans-unit.source: For an example of setting the environment variables in a configuration file for an Azure Cloud Service, see [Node.js Cloud Service with Storage].
trans-unit.target: For an example of setting the environment variables in a configuration file for an Azure Cloud Service, see [Node.js Cloud Service with Storage].

trans-unit.source: For an example of setting the environment variables in the management portal for an Azure Website, see [Node.js Web Application with Storage]
trans-unit.target: For an example of setting the environment variables in the management portal for an Azure Website, see [Node.js Web Application with Storage]

trans-unit.source: How to create a queue
trans-unit.target: How to create a queue

trans-unit.source: The ServiceBusService object enables you to work with queues.
trans-unit.target: The ServiceBusService object enables you to work with queues.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: Add it near the top of the server.js file, after the statement to import the Azure module:
trans-unit.target: Add it near the top of the server.js file, after the statement to import the Azure module:

trans-unit.source: By calling createQueueIfNotExists on the ServiceBusService object, the specified queue will be returned (if it exists,) or a new queue with the specified name will be created.
trans-unit.target: By calling createQueueIfNotExists on the ServiceBusService object, the specified queue will be returned (if it exists,) or a new queue with the specified name will be created.

trans-unit.source: The following code uses createQueueIfNotExists to create or connect to the queue named 'myqueue':
trans-unit.target: The following code uses createQueueIfNotExists to create or connect to the queue named 'myqueue':

trans-unit.source: createServiceBusService also supports additional options, which enable you to override default queue settings such as message time to live or maximum queue size.
trans-unit.target: createServiceBusService also supports additional options, which enable you to override default queue settings such as message time to live or maximum queue size.

trans-unit.source: The following example sets the maximum queue size to 5 GB, and a time to live value of 1 minute:
trans-unit.target: The following example sets the maximum queue size to 5 GB, and a time to live value of 1 minute:

trans-unit.source: Filters
trans-unit.target: Filters

trans-unit.source: Optional filtering operations can be applied to operations performed using ServiceBusService.
trans-unit.target: Optional filtering operations can be applied to operations performed using ServiceBusService.

trans-unit.source: Filtering operations can include logging, automatically retrying, etc.
trans-unit.target: Filtering operations can include logging, automatically retrying, etc.

trans-unit.source: Filters are objects that implement a method with the signature:
trans-unit.target: Filters are objects that implement a method with the signature:

trans-unit.source: After doing its pre-processing on the request options, the method must call next, passing a callback with the following signature:
trans-unit.target: After doing its pre-processing on the request options, the method must call next, passing a callback with the following signature:

trans-unit.source: In this callback, and after processing the returnObject (the response from the request to the server), the callback must either invoke next if it exists to continue processing other filters, or simply invoke finalCallback, which ends the service invocation.
trans-unit.target: In this callback, and after processing the returnObject (the response from the request to the server), the callback must either invoke next if it exists to continue processing other filters, or simply invoke finalCallback, which ends the service invocation.

trans-unit.source: Two filters that implement retry logic are included with the Azure SDK for Node.js, ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter and LinearRetryPolicyFilter.
trans-unit.target: Two filters that implement retry logic are included with the Azure SDK for Node.js, ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter and LinearRetryPolicyFilter.

trans-unit.source: The following creates a ServiceBusService object that uses the ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter:
trans-unit.target: The following creates a ServiceBusService object that uses the ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter:

trans-unit.source: How to send messages to a queue
trans-unit.target: How to send messages to a queue

trans-unit.source: To send a message to a Service Bus queue, your application calls the sendQueueMessage method on the ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: To send a message to a Service Bus queue, your application calls the sendQueueMessage method on the ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: Messages sent to (and received from) Service Bus queues are BrokeredMessage objects, and have a set of standard properties (such as Label and TimeToLive), a dictionary that is used to hold custom application specific properties, and a body of arbitrary application data.
trans-unit.target: Messages sent to (and received from) Service Bus queues are BrokeredMessage objects, and have a set of standard properties (such as Label and TimeToLive), a dictionary that is used to hold custom application specific properties, and a body of arbitrary application data.

trans-unit.source: An application can set the body of the message by passing a string as the message.
trans-unit.target: An application can set the body of the message by passing a string as the message.

trans-unit.source: Any required standard properties are populated with default values.
trans-unit.target: Any required standard properties are populated with default values.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to send a test message to the queue named myqueue using sendQueueMessage:
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to send a test message to the queue named myqueue using sendQueueMessage:

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues support a maximum message size of 256 KB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 KB).
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues support a maximum message size of 256 KB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 KB).

trans-unit.source: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a queue but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a queue.
trans-unit.target: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a queue but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a queue.

trans-unit.source: This queue size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.
trans-unit.target: This queue size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.

trans-unit.source: How to receive messages from a queue
trans-unit.target: How to receive messages from a queue

trans-unit.source: Messages are received from a queue using the receiveQueueMessage method on the ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: Messages are received from a queue using the receiveQueueMessage method on the ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: By default, messages are deleted from the queue as they are read; however, you can read (peek) and lock the message without deleting it from the queue by setting the optional parameter isPeekLock to true.
trans-unit.target: By default, messages are deleted from the queue as they are read; however, you can read (peek) and lock the message without deleting it from the queue by setting the optional parameter isPeekLock to true.

trans-unit.source: The default behavior of reading and deleting the message as part of the receive operation is the simplest model, and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.
trans-unit.target: The default behavior of reading and deleting the message as part of the receive operation is the simplest model, and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.

trans-unit.source: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.
trans-unit.target: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.

trans-unit.source: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.
trans-unit.target: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.

trans-unit.source: If the isPeekLock parameter is set to true, the receive becomes a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.
trans-unit.target: If the isPeekLock parameter is set to true, the receive becomes a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.

trans-unit.source: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.
trans-unit.target: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.

trans-unit.source: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling deleteMessage method and providing the message to be deleted as a parameter.
trans-unit.target: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling deleteMessage method and providing the message to be deleted as a parameter.

trans-unit.source: The deleteMessage method will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the queue.
trans-unit.target: The deleteMessage method will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the queue.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to receive and process messages using receiveQueueMessage.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to receive and process messages using receiveQueueMessage.

trans-unit.source: The example first receives and deletes a message, and then receives a message using isPeekLock set to true, then deletes the message using deleteMessage:
trans-unit.target: The example first receives and deletes a message, and then receives a message using isPeekLock set to true, then deletes the message using deleteMessage:

trans-unit.source: How to handle application crashes and unreadable messages
trans-unit.target: How to handle application crashes and unreadable messages

trans-unit.source: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.

trans-unit.source: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlockMessage method on the ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlockMessage method on the ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: This will cause Service Bus to unlock the
trans-unit.target: This will cause Service Bus to unlock the

trans-unit.source: message within the queue and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.
trans-unit.target: message within the queue and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.

trans-unit.source: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the queue, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then Service Bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.
trans-unit.target: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the queue, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then Service Bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.

trans-unit.source: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the deleteMessage method is called, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.
trans-unit.target: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the deleteMessage method is called, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.

trans-unit.source: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.
trans-unit.target: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.

trans-unit.source: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.
trans-unit.target: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.

trans-unit.source: This is often achieved using the MessageId property of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.
trans-unit.target: This is often achieved using the MessageId property of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.
